question: Can we track material identity through a folio by reading its paragraphs sequentially?

signals: Low specificity rate (23.7%): vocabulary shared across paragraphs
Kernel varies ({'ESCAPE_DOMINANT', 'BALANCED'}) but vocabulary overlaps (avg Jaccard 0.24)
f103r.material_reading: SHARED VOCABULARY (avg Jaccard 0.24): High overlap suggests material continuity, though no single rare MIDDLE dominates. Material identity may be distributed across common vocabulary rather than marked by rare tokens.

signals: Kernel varies ({'ESCAPE_DOMINANT', 'HAZARD_HEAVY', 'BALANCED'}) but vocabulary overlaps (avg Jaccard 0.19)
f39r.material_reading: INDEPENDENT PROGRAMS: Low vocabulary overlap (avg Jaccard 0.19) and no persistent rare MIDDLEs. Each paragraph appears to operate on different material or the same material with different vocabulary focus.

signals: Kernel varies ({'ESCAPE_DOMINANT', 'BALANCED'}) but vocabulary overlaps (avg Jaccard 0.27)
f86v3.material_reading: SHARED VOCABULARY (avg Jaccard 0.27): High overlap suggests material continuity, though no single rare MIDDLE dominates. Material identity may be distributed across common vocabulary rather than marked by rare tokens.

signals: Kernel varies ({'ESCAPE_DOMINANT', 'NO_KERNELS', 'BALANCED'}) but vocabulary overlaps (avg Jaccard 0.15)
f66r.material_reading: INDEPENDENT PROGRAMS: Low vocabulary overlap (avg Jaccard 0.15) and no persistent rare MIDDLEs. Each paragraph appears to operate on different material or the same material with different vocabulary focus.

signals: Low specificity rate (21.2%): vocabulary shared across paragraphs
Kernel varies ({'ESCAPE_DOMINANT', 'HAZARD_HEAVY', 'ENERGY_DOMINANT', 'BALANCED'}) but vocabulary overlaps (avg Jaccard 0.18)
f107r.material_reading: INDEPENDENT PROGRAMS: Low vocabulary overlap (avg Jaccard 0.18) and no persistent rare MIDDLEs. Each paragraph appears to operate on different material or the same material with different vocabulary focus.

signals: Low specificity rate (21.3%): vocabulary shared across paragraphs
Kernel varies ({'ESCAPE_DOMINANT', 'ENERGY_DOMINANT', 'BALANCED'}) but vocabulary overlaps (avg Jaccard 0.28)
f103v.material_reading: SHARED VOCABULARY (avg Jaccard 0.28): High overlap suggests material continuity, though no single rare MIDDLE dominates. Material identity may be distributed across common vocabulary rather than marked by rare tokens.

methodology_notes: Paragraphs are INDEPENDENT operational units (C855), not sequential stages
Material persistence is detected by MIDDLEs appearing across operationally independent paragraphs
Folio-persistent rare MIDDLEs are the strongest material signal
Jaccard similarity measures vocabulary overlap between paragraphs
Specificity rate measures what fraction of each paragraphs vocabulary is unique to it

f103r.narrative: f103r has 12 paragraphs, overwhelmingly ESCAPE_DOMINANT. No MIDDLE appears in all 12 paragraphs -- the vocabulary turns over completely. However, the specificity rate is low (23.7%), meaning most MIDDLEs in any given paragraph also appear in other paragraphs. The shared vocabulary is common grammatical infrastructure (edy, ey, k, or, ol, etc.), not rare material-specific tokens. Paragraph-initial MIDDLEs (echypc in P1, ed in P2) do not form a consistent material introduction pattern. Material markers ANIMAL and WATER are consistent across paragraphs, but these are driven by common suffixes (ey, ol, or) that appear universally across Currier B.
f103r.material_reading: If single-material: the material is a generic delicate-plant substance processed with extensive settling (escape-dominant kernel balance). No rare vocabulary marker identifies the specific plant. If multi-material: no evidence of material switching between paragraphs, as each paragraph uses the same common vocabulary pool.
f103r.interpretation: OPERATIONAL_VARIATION -- vocabulary overlap reflects shared grammar, not shared material. The kernel balance uniformity (11/12 ESCAPE_DOMINANT) actually argues AGAINST material variation (all paragraphs process similarly), but the vocabulary that shifts between paragraphs is operational, not material.

f39r.narrative: f39r shows the most varied kernel balance profile: BALANCED, HAZARD_HEAVY, BALANCED, ESCAPE_DOMINANT, BALANCED, ESCAPE_DOMINANT. This folio has the lowest Jaccard similarity (avg 0.19) and highest specificity rate (38.3%) -- each paragraph uses substantially different vocabulary. The P1 header is a 13-token HT identification line. No MIDDLEs persist across all paragraphs. The gallows-initial boundary tokens vary: tedo, tohedy, pchdaiin, tchedy, pchdar, tolchdaiin -- diverse morphological openings suggesting different operational contexts. Paragraphs are truly independent with minimal vocabulary sharing.
f39r.material_reading: If single-material: the material is set by the header (P1 line 1) and does not need to be re-established. The vocabulary variation across paragraphs is entirely operational -- different processing modes (hazard monitoring, balanced processing, settling) applied to the same material. If multi-material: the high specificity and low overlap could indicate different materials in each paragraph, but the absence of any folio-persistent rare MIDDLE provides no positive evidence for this.
f39r.interpretation: INDEPENDENT_PROGRAMS -- each paragraph is a truly separate operation. Material context, if any, is established once in the folio header and not tracked through vocabulary.

f86v3.narrative: f86v3 has only 3 paragraphs but the highest per-paragraph vocabulary. P1 is a 59-token block with 31 tokens in a single header line -- an unusually dense HT identification line. P2 is the dominant paragraph (177 tokens, 9 lines, 63 unique MIDDLEs) containing the bulk of the folio's content. 11 MIDDLEs appear in all 3 paragraphs (aiin, dy, ed, edy, eo, ey, k, kch, or, r, t), but ALL are common MIDDLEs (appearing in 40+ folios). The material markers span all categories (ANIMAL, WATER, ROOT, OIL), which is more likely a sign that this folio covers multiple processing types than a single material. The Jaccard values (0.25-0.32) reflect shared common grammar.
f86v3.material_reading: If single-material: the material involves multiple processing modes (balanced P1 header + escape-dominant P2 body + balanced P3 closing). The ALL-category marker spread could indicate an animal-origin material requiring oil extraction and water processing. If multi-material: the P2 paragraph's massive size and distinct vocabulary suggest it is the primary operation, with P1 and P3 as framing operations.
f86v3.interpretation: SHARED_GRAMMAR -- the folio-wide MIDDLEs are all high-frequency common tokens. Material identity is NOT tracked through MIDDLE vocabulary.

f66r.narrative: f66r has 8 paragraphs with the lowest average Jaccard (0.15). The vocabulary is highly paragraph-specific. Notably, paragraphs P2-P5 all start with boundary token 'f' (gallows), which is morphologically minimal -- possibly a section T pattern rather than a material marker. P8 is degenerate (2 tokens, NO_KERNELS). The first paragraph P1 is headerless (starts with 'y', an articulator). Material markers ANIMAL and WATER are consistent but driven by common suffixes. The paragraph-initial MIDDLEs show no pattern: iin (P1), cph/f (P2), eol/f/lcheeek (P3), edy/f/r (P4), de/f/o (P5), etc.
f66r.material_reading: If single-material: the material is processed in 8 independent operational modes with very little vocabulary overlap. The consistent ANIMAL markers suggest animal-origin material. If multi-material: the low Jaccard and high paragraph-specificity could indicate 8 different material operations, but the 'f' boundary token repetition argues against this.
f66r.interpretation: OPERATIONAL_VARIATION -- the 'f' gallows repetition suggests a single operational template applied repeatedly with different specific vocabulary, not different materials.

f107r.narrative: f107r has the most paragraphs (18) and the widest kernel balance variation: ESCAPE_DOMINANT, BALANCED, ENERGY_DOMINANT, and HAZARD_HEAVY all present. This is the original trigger folio for material investigation. With 18 small paragraphs (many just 1-3 lines), the folio reads as a recipe collection rather than a single process. The low specificity (21.2%) combined with moderate Jaccard (0.18) suggests paragraphs draw from a shared vocabulary pool. Many paragraphs start with distinctive boundary tokens: pchdlar, teeody, torshor, polchls, tolshosor -- these are morphologically complex and folio-specific. Each boundary token could be naming a recipe variant or sub-procedure. No rare MIDDLEs persist across the 18 paragraphs.
f107r.material_reading: If single-material: the 18 paragraphs represent 18 independent operations on the same material (consistent with C855 PARALLEL_PROGRAMS). The diversity of kernel balances (heating, settling, monitoring, hazard-control) supports this -- different processing phases. If multi-material: the paragraph boundary tokens (torshor, polchls, tolshosor, etc.) could be material labels, but they are all morphologically distinct with no shared rare MIDDLE suggesting material continuity.
f107r.interpretation: RECIPE_COLLECTION -- f107r functions as a multi-recipe folio. Material identity, if present, is set at the folio level (section S context) and not tracked through paragraph vocabulary.

f103v.narrative: f103v has 11 paragraphs and the highest average Jaccard (0.28) of all folios tested. The low specificity (21.3%) means paragraphs share most of their vocabulary. Multiple paragraph pairs exceed 0.40 Jaccard: P1-P2 (0.40), P1-P5 (0.41), P3-P7 (0.43), P5-P9 (0.46). This is the strongest vocabulary continuity signal in the dataset. However, the folio-wide MIDDLEs set is empty (no MIDDLE appears in all 11 paragraphs). The shared vocabulary is common tokens. Material markers ANIMAL and WATER are consistent. The paragraphs show typical S-section escape-dominant processing.
f103v.material_reading: If single-material: f103v shows the strongest case for a single material processed 11 ways. The high pairwise Jaccard values suggest the same operational vocabulary is reused across paragraphs, consistent with a single material context. If multi-material: no evidence supports material switching -- no paragraph-specific rare vocabularies form clusters.
f103v.interpretation: BEST_CANDIDATE_SINGLE_MATERIAL -- among all 6 folios, f103v shows the strongest vocabulary continuity. However, even here the shared vocabulary is common tokens, not material-specific rare MIDDLEs.

overall_synthesis.key_finding: No folio has folio-persistent rare MIDDLEs. No folio has majority-persistent rare MIDDLEs. The strongest material signal type (rare vocabulary appearing across operationally independent paragraphs) is completely absent.
overall_synthesis.what_IS_shared: Common grammatical infrastructure MIDDLEs (edy, ey, k, or, ol, ed, etc.) appear across paragraphs. These are the 41 MIDDLEs found in 40+ folios. They carry operational, not material, meaning.
overall_synthesis.what_varies: Paragraph-specific MIDDLEs are either rare compound forms (keodai, lcheeek, cphhof) that appear as one-off hapax legomena, or section-typical vocabulary that appears in some but not all paragraphs.
overall_synthesis.material_markers_are_generic: ANIMAL and WATER markers fire consistently because they are driven by common suffixes (ey, ol, or, al) that are part of the base grammar. Their consistency across paragraphs reflects grammar, not material continuity.
overall_synthesis.vocabulary_overlap_is_grammatical: Jaccard values of 0.15-0.28 reflect shared grammar, not shared material. The same common MIDDLEs appear in all paragraphs because they are the grammatical building blocks, not because they encode a persistent material.
overall_synthesis.conclusion: Material identity is NOT tracked through paragraph-level MIDDLE vocabulary. If material is encoded, it is either (a) set once at the folio level and never restated, (b) encoded through a mechanism other than MIDDLE vocabulary (e.g., prefix combinations, suffix patterns, or structural position), or (c) not encoded through vocabulary at all but rather through the folio's section membership.
